titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: I travelled to London by the early train, and, after leaving my bags in Park Lane, went on to Westminster, where I attended the meeting of the Patronage Commission. I lunched at the House of Lords, & then wrote to Ella. After attending the Commission until 4 p.m., I returned to the H. of Lords, where I took the oath and attended the House. Lord Olivier, the new Secretary for India, made a long speech (1 hour & 20 minutes) which I found difficulty in hearing. Curzon spoke admirably for 50 minutes. I hastened to Park Lane, & changed. I dined with the Club. There were but five members present viz Lord Stamfordham, Lord Crawford, Lord Dunedin, Sir H. Newbolt & myself. We talked a great deal, but not very fruitfully! Lord S. asked me about Walters, who was once a curate of mine. He seemed to have impressed him as a preacher. Lord S. said that he would be glad if I could recommend to him any of my clergy who, in my opinion, might fairly be asked to preach to H.M. I am afraid there is not much use in suggesting men who read & think. They would "preach over the King's head", as Lord S. phrases it! Rank and jocosity are the requisites!
